passage_text: Azaleas are considered flowering shrubs of the rhododendron family. Azalea flowers bloom in the spring, but die back in the fall. Flower colors include white, orange, red and purple. These shrubs grow from 2 and 8 feet in height. Azalea bushes grow best in USDA hardiness zones 5 through 8b.

Azaleas are in the plant genus of rhododendrons. Over 10,000 different azaleas have been named so there are a large selection of sizes, flower colors, and bloom times to choose from when selecting an azalea plant. A wide variety of flower colors and patterns are also offered in the azalea family.

R hododendrons and azaleas are arguably the South’s favorite shrubs. Many people think of them as entirely different plants, but they both belong to the genus Rhododendron, which comprises more than 800 species and 10,000 named selections.
